newsitem.title: USA: Integrated Device sees weak Q1 results.
newsitem.headline: Integrated Device sees weak Q1 results.

text.p: Integrated Device Technology Inc said Wednesday it expects earnings for its first fiscal quarter will be below analysts' expectations and its earnings for the preceeding quarter.

Analysts had expected the company to report first quarter earnings of $0.06 a share compared with profits of $0.11 a share in the year-ago period, according to First Call. The company said it expects to report a profit for its first quarter but that it will fall below fourth quarter levels.
The company had fourth quarter profits of $2.1 million, or $0.03 a share on revenues $143.2 million.

Integrated Device said in a statement that revenues for the June quarter will be flat to slightly up compared with the fourth quarter. The company's book-to- bill ratio for the first quarter is expected to be about 1.0.

The company attributed the weaker than expected results to lower than anticipated demand, particularly in the PC-related business segments. The PC sector accounted for about 22 percent of Integrated Device's revenue in the most recent fiscal year.
"We had strong bookings early in the month of April, but since then the order rate has softened," President and Chief Executive Len Perham said in a statement.

Perham said the weakness was concentrated in the static random access memory modules used in personal computers and to a lesser extent, logic components used by dynamic random access memory module vendors.
"A slowing of PC-related demand, together with typical seasonal weakness in the summer months, are reasons to be cautious," Perham said.
He said he still expects significant revenue growth and improved profitability over the coming year.
